B0007DAZW8|5.0|I first have to admit that this album is fairly repetitive. <br />There, now that I've laid out the base, I can honestly explain what makes this album excellent. <br /> <br />The limited lyrics. <br /> I find these fascinating because it allows you to concentrate on one phrase for an entire song.  You can either ignore the repetition, or you can really think about it.  In my opinion, this whole album is very negative in its view of the effect of technology on modern life.  From track two, \\"Prime Time of your Life,\\" I interpreted this as a call for people to realize that now, right now, they're living their life.  Prime time on TV shouldn't even be worthy of your notice because you're already involved in a much more interesting story yourself.  Certainly I'm reading a lot into this, but their lack of definite lyrics gives a lot of freedom to the listener.  I enjoy being able to think about their songs like this. <br /> <br />The loops. <br />If you notice carefully, these are not really looped, but elements are introduced and removed at different times.  There is a very subtle interaction between all the elements, and I enjoy listening for these changes.  Even the timing of when the samples are introduced and re-introduced is very interesting. <br /> <br />This album probably works on two very different levels.  One, if you're really dumb and just like the repetition.  Or two, if you're willing to listen for all the subtleties in the music.  I wouldn't rate this album as high as Discovery, but I think it's a work that can stand on its own.  Before you trash it, give a good listening to someplace without too much noise where you can hear and concentrate on the details.  Once you've done this, then if you don't like it, point taken.  But at least look for the skillful structure Daft Punk wove into these songs. <br />

B000929AJQ|5.0|First off, I gotta say the amazon review is completely wrong:  Trent reznor is not a one trick pony.  If one listened to 'The Downward Spiral' and then put 'The Fragile' on right after, one would immediately notice the differences in composition, instrumentation, singing, EVERYTHING; same goes for all of His albums. A one trick pony would be... Celine Dion... yes.   I will say that there are elements from 'The Fragile' that I immediately noticed. Actually, it would be more accurate to call the elements 'samples' or 'instruments'.  The bass in 'The Collector' is very similar to that of the bass in 'Into the Void' on 'The Fragile'.  A synth that comes in the second half of each verse of 'Everyday Is Exactly the Same' is the same synth in 'We're In This Together Now' of 'The Fragile'.  There are undoubtedly more similarities that exist between the two albums ('With Teeth' and 'The Fragile')but they, the albums, are completely different. 'The Hand That Feeds' could almost be on 'Pretty Hate Machine', with that reverb on the voice and the straight-up drum beat, but then the solo comes in and you're like, 'That wouldn't be on Pretty Hate Machine'.  Ok, here's one way to look at it; compare, 'The Bends' by Radiohead to their later 'Kid A'... that's all I should have to say.  Compare 'Pretty Hate Machine' to 'The Fragile'... Same thing, only, I think that 'The Fragile' is much, much more expansive, intricate, and deeper than 'Kid A', don't get me wrong.  That one trick pony comment just really made me mad... don't believe it! Whoever wrote that is completely wrong on that point.  I do agree though, that is perhaps the most focused NIN album.  Trent Reznor is definitely the most talented musician/songwriter alive.  A good summary?  I'd say a concentrated Fragile, with rock thrown in... and AWESOME production. BUY IT!!!!!
B00005JNBQ|5.0|I'd been hearing about Napoleon Dynamite for some time and finally at the urging of one of my friends, sat down and watched it. This film is definitely a sleeper, you will need to watch it multiple times to truly appreciate it. Jon Heder does a bang-up job as Napoleon Dynamite, a not so typical nerd. Napoleon lives with his brother and grandmother who is injured early on in the film during a ATV accident. Enter Uncle Rico who comes to look after the boys during his grandmothers absence. Uncle Rico is stuck in the year 1982 his football glory years and cannot get past the fact that he was on the bench during the State Championship. He's pretty much Matt Foley in other words he lives in a van down by the river. Napoleon and Uncle Rico clash from the get go to hilarious results. There are some side-splitting scenes including the time machine bit, throwing the button and Napoleon's lament over not having any skills that girls would find attractive (\\"I don't have any good skills...you know like nunchuck skills\\"). When a new student, Pedro Sanchez, enters the school, Napoleon befriends him and the rest is history. Not much happens during the running time of Napoleon Dynamite but ultimately I could not keep my eyes off it. Heder does such a fantastic job as the main character that we are left wanting to know more about him. The dance sketch following Pedro's speech was no less inspirational than Rocky taking Apollo Creed to the brink in the original. Napoleon Dynamite celebrates diversity and leaves the viewer with a great almost simplistic message...it's not what you look like on the outside that matters, it's what's on the inside that counts. This film is nothing short of a diamond in the rough. A Must-Own addition to your DVD collection. Highest Recommendation.

B0008ISM40|4.0|I've rarely seen such mixed reviews!  However, they all agree on the fact that this is an unexpected direction for Trent to take.  What With Teeth boils down to is nothing more than just rock album done NIN style.  This album is not a dark journey where the songs all meld into a single theme like The Downward Spiral, nor is it an epic concept piece like The Fragile.  This is about making a record you can listen to and enjoy for what it is at face value.  I'd say it's built like Pretty Hate Machine, however I disagree with the other reviewers that it sounds just like that album.  With Teeth definitely has its own sound. <br /> <br />The first listen will be strange, since you have all these expectations.  I promise you, you will be somewhat let down as it's not going to be what you expect.  But on subsequent listens, you'll know what kind of album it is, and you'll start listening to it with a new set of expectations, and this time you'll begin to appreciate what With Teeth has to offer.  That's when the true beauty of this album shows itself.  This is why there are so many negative reviews...people aren't giving it a chance. <br /> <br />Trent Reznor begins the album in a different way.  Instead of something loud and angry, it's something somber, quiet and melodic.  The song is \\"All The Love In The World\\", which is one of the best NIN songs I've heard.  From there the record launches into a nice variety of styles.  You have the afore-mentioned loud and angry songs (\\"You Know What You Are?\\", \\"Getting Smaller\\"), and you have your beat-driven songs (\\"The Hand That Feeds\\", \\"Only\\"), your experimental song (\\"Beside You In Time\\") and your ballad (\\"Right Where It Belongs\\"). <br /> <br />I personally like \\"Only\\", which is slightly reminiscent of \\"Down In It\\" without the heaviness.  Also, the one-two combination ending of \\"Beside You In Time\\" and \\"Right Where It Belongs\\" is simply beautiful (word to those comparing the last track with \\"Hurt\\", this is NOTHING like \\"Hurt\\"..it'ssomething totally new). <br /> <br /> <br />You've heard songs that sound like this before in other NIN albums, but they don't sound exactly like any song.  It's a great record...these songs just scream for being done live!  Any NIN fan should like this, and any fan of rock should find this fresh and invigorating in the genre.

B0008ISM40|2.0|First off, I am (was?) a serious NIN fan, owning all the prior haloes.  I thought the Fragile was the best album Trent ever did.  With Teeth, on the other hand, has no bite. 0440237688|4.0|I was required to read a modern fantasy novel as part of the course requirement for a Children's Literature course which I am currently enrolled in.  I selected \\"The Giver\\" and was very pleased with my choice.   <br /> <br />I found it to be a thought provoking book that encourages the reader to evaluate his or her own position on matters such as life and death, right and wrong, good and evil.  Lowry was able to create an idealistic utopian society where outwardly things seem to be ideal.  However, upon closer inspection, the reader realizes that in this fictional world where there is no existance of war, hunger or poverty, there is also no evidence of emotion or freedom of choice.   <br /> <br />Provocative subject matter and the author's use of descriptive langueage makes \\"The Giver\\" a wonderful book for readers of all ages.

Barbara Carrera's character is infinitely more interesting than Kim Basinger's basic bimbo, so the movie suffers when her scenes end.  I'd hoped, since this was a one-shot deal, that Connery would finally face Ernst Stavro Blofeld, but the script remains too faithful to the basic framework of THUNDERBALL.<br /><br />I'd read an interview with Connery and he said the filming of NEVER SAY NEVER was a disaster, that it was more frustrating than his six previous Bond films put together. B0007XT87G|4.0|After reading the various reviews, I thought I would venture a review myself.    This album is extraordinary.  It comes from a maturing and changing band.  To me, it represents (as does the band) the definition of \\"Progressive Rock.\\"  For the complaints of the album relying on heavy metal riffs, they are not justified.   I believe the heavy riffs are a statement and expression of the attitude and feeling Wilson is conveying.  I believe this expression is best described and understood when the album is played in its entirety.  The music is based upon a screenplay.  Not every movie in the theater should give you the feeling you get when you listen to \\"The Sky Moves Sideways\\" or \\"Stars Die.\\"  I believe that this is close to P-Tree's best work. B000002UZ4|5.0|Actually I have to thank Kylie..I bought her greatest hits package \\"Ultimate\\" because I mildly like some of her songs...At the cash register, the cashgirl recommended that if I liked Kylie, I would definitely like this band and offered me Discography. With a synth-pop band from other side of Atlantic? What was she thinking? But enough is enough I eventually paid and drove home. <br /> <br />I first listened Kylie but it got thin after a couple of songs- same melodies, same ussh hissshh, same number over and over- very good for jumping on the disco floor but not so exciting to make you go on a dreamland and the lyrics are simply stupid. <br /> <br />Then I put Discography on the stereo...listened two first songs with amusing curiousity-lyrics and structure of the songs were quite interesting- but then the real stomper arrived knocking on all doors of my life: Opportunities...and the rest is just a story, as they say, and I simply fell in love with them. <br /> <br />There is not a single bad or insipid song in the album. Can you believe it?. From the first tunes of West End Girls until the end of Was it Worth it, it almost flows like a magic walk through clouds, through heaven, you laugh, you cry, you dance, you sing, you tap your feet, you think, you are depressed...God, you make everything that music should make you. <br /> <br />But what's more important is the band's striking intelligence...lyrics, structures, compositions, backvocals, production, small touches...are all very well calculated and sincere, just for the sake of making things more fun. Melodies are incredibly catchy and also very complex...miles better than anything Erasure (whom I listened afterwards upon Amazon recommendaton but not impressed) can achieve in their lifetime. <br /> <br />Particular highlights of highlights: Opportunities...Suburbia...What have I done (not surprised Dusty agreed to duet), It's A Sin, Always On My Mind (oh a tepid Elvis song becomes an unbelievably disco stomping piece but what an underlying sadness my friends), Heart, Left To My Own Devices, It's Alright, So Hard,DJ Culture...See, almost the entire album.. <br /> <br />Well I have been missing a very important thing in my life and I am sure millions of Americans are still missing it. If only I had the chance to promote them through the Promised Land.  <br /> <br />All in all, Discography is a must and Pet Shop Boys are true and clever wizards of Pop. Now back to backcatalogue- my first click on purchase items in Amazon: Please, the first album that started the ball to roll on. <br /> <br />Feverishly recommended!

B00005JNDZ|3.0|The essential problem with the second Bridget Jones film is that the best parts remind the viewer of parts of the first film that were done a whole lot better.  It is a pleasant enough movie, but not so pleasant that I would recommend it over taking a risk on any other film or doing something safe like rewatching an episode of BUFFY.  I haven't read the book upon which the second film is based, so perhaps it is to blame for the relative blandness of the sequel, but something is to blame for the fact that while the original was charming and entertaining, the sequel feels tired and derivative.  But even if the book is to blame, it is incumbent upon anyone making a sequel to try to find some way of making the second film in some way new, instead of merely recycling the first.  In this regard, the movie fails.<br /><br />An additional problem I had with this movie is that it took some of the weaker aspects of the original even further than it had done.  For instance, one of the sources of the original was Bridget's penchant for making a bit of an ass out of herself.  Despite this, she constantly manages to come across as cute and adorable, but in the second film she merely looks ridiculous.  The first film presented Bridget as a sympathetic character, but she was much harder to love in the second.  Again, the fault may lie with the source material, but it is important for any filmmakers, when confronted with a weak source, to make it stronger in the rewrite.<br /><br />As with the original, Renee Zellweger is delightful as Bridget, and she remains the main reason for watching the film.  She is one of my favorite contemporary actresses, and someone who hasn't done the range of performances that I would have liked to see her take on.  I miss the days when she did small, independent films like THE WHOLE WIDE WORLD.  She looks a bit plumper in this one than in the original, and it is interesting that one of the more celebrated non-anorexic characters of reason years would be played twice by one of the thinnest actresses in the movies.  On the other hand, I didn't like either Colin Firth or Hugh Grant as much in this film as in the former.  The interesting thing about Mark Darcy (just as with his namesake from the BBC production of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE-not a slip on my part, because Ms Fielding acknowledges that the model for Darcy was Colin Firth's performance in the six-hour BBC production of the Jane Austen classic) in the first film was in gradually learning about his true feelings about Bridget.  There was no such mystery in this one.  Likewise, knowing from the original that Daniel Cleaver was a deceptive, manipulative creep made him a pretty uninteresting character in the sequel.  The guys too as good a job as is possible given the limited possibilities of character development, but their roles are too circumvented to allow of much interest.<br /><br />So, do I recommend this or not?  I really am on the fence.  I guess I'm glad I saw it, but if I hadn't I would have been able to preserve more fully my respect for the original.  Sequels can often mar excellent originals (think of the MATRIX movies), but still leave an overall surplus of enjoyment.  I guess I liked seeing this one OK, but I can't say now that I would have regretted never having seen it at all.  I suppose that there is no harm in seeing this one, but I would warn anyone who really liked (as I did) the original, that this one falls far short of that superb film.ld be played twice by one of the thinnest actresses in the movies. 0684800713|1.0|I will never understand Ernest Hemingway's appeal.  His labored attempts at understating everything, his affected grittiness, his belief in himself as adventurer and someone who truly experiences life all make me want to throw up.  This book is the perfect example of how terrible he is.   I'll give you some examples from within the book so you can think about it a little more. <br /> <br /> Number one is Brett.  The \\"heroine\\" of the book, she is a heartless 34-year old nymphomaniac who is self-absorbed and callous, not to mention elitist and stupid.  The \\"hero\\" of the book, manly man Jake, \\"loves\\" her.  What a great love story.  Jake is too \\"injured\\" to make love to her, so she sleeps with a number of other people during the book.   Number two is Cohn.  This character, created out of the author's anti-semitic imagination, is a simpering bookish fool who, the narrator lets us know, is too cowardly to enjoy things like bullfights.  Only a manly man would enjoy the spectacle of a matador being gored by a tortured animal, of course. <br /> <br />Cohn is apparently equally contemptable because he wants to hang out with gentiles (How DARE he?!), but Jake is magnanimous enough to let him.  Brett is magnanimous enough to sleep with him, but looks down on him for being a Jew.  (Lovely people, aren't they?).  Hemingway wants us to revile Cohn because he took the affair with Brett too seriously and actually got jealous when she slept with someone else.  We're supposed to laugh at Cohn's emotionality and inability to be a wasp.   <br /> <br />I can't tell you how pointless this book is.  What's the moral?  Is there one?  I don't think there is.  If a book isn't engrossing, or exciting, or beautifully written (therefore art for art's sake) it has to have a message.  This book fails on all counts.

B000092ZYX|3.0|I'm a big Radiohead fan, but this review will no doubt seperate me from the die-hards. I've heard this album several times since it was first released. Aside from maybe PABLO HONEY, this has to be my least favorite Radiohead album. I just don't connect to these songs very well. They don't stick in my brain the way most other Radiohead songs do.<br /><br />I can't explain it, really. In fact, looking at a lot of these other reviews, many others seem to have a hard time putting their fingers on this one. There are clearly moments of beauty. There are even guitars that sound exactly like guitars. Much of it certainly qualifies as rock music. Yet words like oblique and inscrutable seem fitting. Some might use these words to describe the more experimental KID A and AMNESIAC albums, but I connect to those two far more than HAIL TO THE THIEF and love them much more as well. Songs like the achingly hesitant, positively heavenly \\"Pyramid Song\\" or the spell-binding, propulsive \\"Idioteque\\" have made much more of an impression on me.<br /><br />I thought deeper appreciation would come with repeated listens, and it has to a certain degree, but alas, I still find this album impenetrable. Also, what's with the album title? It's clever, especially in reference to President Bush (Yorke wouldn't be specific about its meaning from what I've read), but I can't figure out how it relates to the record itself.
192076920X|5.0|This is one of those rare books that you will remember having read for a long time. There are many things to say about it, but to cut it short, it brought back to me what it was like to be in Bombay, what it was like to be a romantic, and be in love, and what it was like to know that philosophy is for everybody, not just for an intellectual elite. The most important thing about this book is that it engages with all the big questions in an authentic way. It is also a very good read, without too many concessions to clichs. Finally, the book has one specific lesson for us to ponder: the worst evil is not in the world of crime, but in the institutionalised prison and police jail.   <br />The hero, in fact, may be a criminal of sorts. <br />Many thanks for this book. It joins books by Sandor Marai, William Faulkner, Dashiell Hammett, and a few others in my very special list of novels that reminded me of (or taugut me) something important.
B000929AJQ|5.0|The man himself did it again. A masterpiece that will grow in you as you become more and more addicted to this multi-genre album. B0000DYJM6|5.0|Pearl Jam are all in all, the most consistent and lasting grunge band of all time. Every other band to be born out of the music scene in the early 90s has faded away, some tragically. Alice In Chains, Nirvana, and Smashing Pumpkins all were all destroyed by heroin (Jimmy Chamberlian being cut from the Smashing Pumpkins counts, and lets face the truth, Adore and MACHINA are no Gish, Siamese Dream, and Mellon Collie.) Eddie Vedder and his cronies however still stand today.<br />With a lasting career in music and a large range of songs and albums, Pearl Jam have come a long way in their career. Today, Eddie and co. are the same band they were in 91, but indredibly matured musically. With grunge albums Ten and Vs., cryptic and daring albums like Vitalogy and No Code, the upbeat Yield, the spaced out Binaural, and the gritty Riot Act, their is a wealth of b-sides that have been below the surface of their releases for years, which show who Pearl Jam really are at the core.<br />Lost Dogs is an amazing compilation because it shows who Pearl Jam are and what they are all about, greater than any A-side track in their career. We see sides of Pearl Jam that have never been seen by the public eye before, and this is the sound of who Pearl Jam really are below the serious shell we've seen all along.<br />Disc One has all the rockers. Songs like All Night, Undone, Down, Black, Red, and Yellow, Hitchiker, and Don't Gimme No Lip, are songs where Pearl Jam show their hidden rocking, and upbeat side. Down is the greatest example, a song where you could picture Vedder having a fun time in the studio with the band. Gremmie Out Of Control and Leavin' Here are other great examples, where the band is even humurous. These songs were made you could tell, written when the band couldn't help but fool around and have fun in the studio like a teenage garage band, excited about stardom. <br />Disc Two has all the slow, acoustic, melodic songs, these are beatiful songs that just couldn't fit thesound of any of their albums, songs one could play around a bond-fire. Fatal is one of the best songs, and well worth the price of the album. Along with the two best songs of Pearl Jam's career, Footsteps and the incredible Hard To Imagine. Hard To Imagine defines Pearl Jam better than any other song of their career, it is a slow-building epic song, featuring aspects of everything the band has covered throughout seven studio albums. Vedder's voice start out soft and melodic like his later music, and then builds to an anthemic chant that reminds one of Ten and Vs. <br />All in all, this is one of hell of a cd. This is the album that started me off with Pearl Jam, and it is a great place to start. This album shows that Pearl Jam are not just serious about music, that is only the surface of them.

B00005AFMT|5.0|This is one of those wonderful albums that changed my concept of music forever.  I was a KC fan starting around the time of RED, and was fully involved in exploring the music of the time.  Yes, E.L.P., Genesis, U.K., National Health, Zappa, Talking Heads,... were the backbone of my collection, and in the couple of years preceding \\"Discipline\\" I had witnessed what I could only characterize as a creative malaise.  Danceability was paramount, and the long-heard battle cry \\"Death before disco\\" was being replaced with \\"Dance the night away!\\".  Prog-rock mainstays were seemingly being sucked into a black hole of \\"jingle-ism\\" quite possibly co-perpetrated by the record company moguls of the time. Enter Fripp, Belew, Bruford & Levin.           If I had known there was a \\"Discipline\\"-shaped hole in the music world, I would never have been able to foresee the filling of that hole by Crimson.  But immediately upon being grabbed by the first few measures of \\"Elephant Talk\\", I new that I was in uncharted musical waters.  I thought Hendrix could make a guitar feel pain, but wow!... Belew could make it sound like an unmedicated pachyderm having its tusks torn from its cheeks!  Many others have delved into the individual performances delivered by the four gents involved, and I strongly recommend checking out the many commentaries on Amazon, for my part I focus more on the milestone status of the recording, and specifically as an artwork.  It cannot be overstated that this record was a completely new experience for the listener, and considering where popular music has gone since 1981, there is very little rust on these sounds!        With the exception of Tony Levin, whose work I had heard but didn't realize it, I was familiar with most of the previous work produced by the members of this KC lineup, and I think it's safe to say that \\"Discipline\\" proved to be a cathartic culmination of their development as musicians, artists & technicians.  The compositions here are original, captivating, flawlessly performed & never tedious (as I admit some of KC's previous work had been).  There is an amazing range of performance captured here; bombastic, reflective, Frippnotic, clinical, playful, ... everything you could ever want from prog rock (which incidentally, this album is TRULY synonymous with!).  In my opinion that means that the music heard here is not just for casual listening, it is to be allowed to reveal itself over time just as a Kandinsky painting does.  It's not a sofa-sized oil painting of babbling brooks and mountains in the distance.  This album is a master stroke, pitting highly organized and technically demanding (disciplined) arrangements against concepts of urban danger, our animal nature and otherwise chaotic expressions, played out in the straining of Adrian Belew's guitar and vocals, Bruford's near-frantic barrages on drums, Fripp's impeccable creation of soundscapes and Levin's more-than-just-backbone bass riffs.      A fascinating aspect of this album is that although there is an obvious dance thread to much of the sound, my sense at the time when it was released was that any danceability had much more of a tribal (as opposed to a \\"disco\\") intent to it.  It is most likely this injection of dance rhythms (in what could fairly be described as an artistic response to the era in which KC found themselves) along with the injection of Belew's artistic vocal/lyrical style that took the band and their audience where no band had gone before.  For the Crimson fan of the time, this album also offered a refreshing break from the disturbing qualities of previous offerings (e.g. \\"One More Red Nightmare\\", \\"Schizoid Man\\", \\"Red\\", ...) which tended not to release the listener from their metal-grinding hypnotic spell.  The tracks on \\"Discipline\\" tend more to be artworks to be viewed a bit more safely from a few feet away, not as painfully immersive as before, which for some may be a let down, but for me it's easier to crank this album at 100 decibels and actually experience ..... pleasure! The pain of Schizoid Man is still there, but here it's found in a more controlled tension that exists between the four performers, and the overall feeling isn't nearly as dark as so much of Crimson's catalog.           Discussing the content of a recording is so personal, it can effect us on so many levels, so in an effort to help you - the reader - get a better picture of where I'm coming from I've decided to list a few of the albums which I feel are artistically related to \\"Discipline\\".  In no particular order; \\"Speaking in Tongues\\"-Talking Heads, \\"Horses\\"-Patti Smith, \\"Sergeant Pepper's ...-The Beatles, \\"Dark Side of The Moon\\"-Pink Floyd, \\"Brain Salad Surgery\\"-Emerson, Lake & Palmer, \\"The Hissing of Summer Lawns\\"-Joni Mitchell.  If any of these recordings had an effect on you, \\"Discipline\\" almost certainly will leave a lasting impression on you.       In the musak-friendly environment of pop music which can be just as easily ignored as listened to, the performances on \\"Discipline\\" will not only find you thoroughly involved, but will most likely leave you wanting more (try Beat, Three of a Perfect Pair and Thrak).
038572179X|5.0|It's nice to know that in the 21st century, the literary tradition is alive and well.  To say that McEwan's book is reminiscent of great authors as varied as Austen, Forster and Hemingway is not giving McEwan his own credit, although I admit I compared his writing style and storytelling to those same authors as I read the novel.  From the idyllic English countryside scenes in the beginning to the graphic war horrors of later on, McEwan tells a story about an act and its consequences that carry over time.  The final act, set in contemporary times, carries a cruel twist but nonetheless one that makes sense.<br /><br />Simply put, \\"Atonement\\" is one of the best books I've read this year.  That may sound a premature statement as the year isn't even half-over, but I doubt I'll find another book quite as complex and engrossing as this one before December -- not that I'll stop trying.

B00005YU1O|4.0|The first time I saw this movie I was sixteen. I left the theater mightily impressed by the philosophising of its dream characters. I cherished this revelatory impression of the film until I watched it again as a college sophomore, when I realized that many of the profundities upon which the film is based are flimsy at best.     The science is not interpreted by scientists but by philosophers who have not grasped it in its entirety. The politics lacks depth. The movie gives off a self-important air.     Only a few characters mentioned unexplored and interesting premises. I was disappointed that they were left floating while the more cliched philosophical revelations took precedence. The most telling moment of the film included a tortured novelist in - what else? - a dark cafe.      Every character presented himself as an expert, so telling apart the wise from the banal was an interesting exercise.     I did love the animation, however. It captivated me from the very beginning. I felt it was innovative and a pleasure to watch.     The score by the Tosca Tango Orchestra is also notable.     Watching the movie in an actual \\"dream state\\" or trance may make it more stimulating. Otherwise, its revelations soon wear thin.

B0006IIKS0|5.0|The filmmakers who brought you Brother's Keeper spent several years following the members of Metallica between therapy exercises and recording sessions, and the result is a fabulous documentary that will entertain fans and non-fans alike.<br /><br />The group has been divided by a bitter breakup with their bassist, writer/singer James Hetfield has gone into seclusion/rehab, and the band has not recorded for quite a while.  As they attempt to reunite and record St. Anger, they also decide that group therapy would be beneficial and it might be fun to have a documentary crew follow them around!  I'm not sure how they decided all this pressure was a good idea, but it sure makes for a wonderful film.<br /><br />Along the way we meet fans, parents and kids; Lars sells his art collection; the band auditions and selects a new bass player; and, in the funniest scene of the film, the group's therapist decides to submit lyrics to the band!  I also enjoyed the moment when Lars is being interviewed in his home, talking about writing music and performing; in the background we hear a little voice repeating, \\"Daddy!  Daddy!\\" and Ulrich, metal rocker extraordinaire, interrupts his musings on the meaning of art to say, \\"What is it, sweetie?\\"  Priceless.<br /><br />I watched this, then watched it with the band's commentary, then watched it again with my husband -- and thoroughly enjoyed it each time.  I'd recommend this to fans of Metallica, to non-fans who like documentaries, and to people who are interested in people.  While the making of an album is not the primary focus of the film (although, ironically, that was the original intent of it), we do still learn some very interesting things about that process, and we come to appreciate the hard work it takes to stay relevant and entertaining.<br /><br />Extras include two commentary tracks, one with the filmmakers and one with Metallica, and 2 trailers.  Subtitles are available in English or Spanish.<br /><br />The second disc contains scenes from various premieres and film festivals as well as 41 deleted scenes, including a tour of Kirk's skull-rich home, a webchat with the lads, a surprisingly prescient management discussion about the benefits of therapy for the band, bowling, Kirk in traffic school, and a terrific segment featuring a collaboration between Kirk, Lars, Swizz Beatz and Ja Rule.<br /><br />Highly recommended.lm festivals as well as 41 deleted scenes, including a tour of Kirk's skull-rich home, a webchat with the lads, a surprisingly prescient management discussion about the benefits of therapy for the band, bowling, Kirk in traffic school, and a terrific segment featuring a collaboration between Kirk, Lars, Swizz Beatz and Ja Rule. B0006IIPIK|4.0|This film  is set between the two world wars, and does a good job of capturing the spirit and feel of the old serials from the 40s, as a mad scientist decides to destroy Earth, only to be dogged by an intrepid pilot and his feisty ex-girlfriend reporter. B00003CX9E|3.0|I have seen this film at the top(or near) of nearly every film list I've ever seen.  Prior to my viewings of the film, a few of my friends(who also take a keen interest in films) urged me to watch it attentively.  Having seen the film twice now, I can't help but doubt film-critics calling this film the best of all time.  Perhaps this is a result of my youth and ignorance, but I suspect the movie has aged poorly and that people of my generation will never truly appreciate this film. <br />  Citizen Kane meets all the criteria of a classic film, the most important of which is: it deals with themes that are universal.  That is, Kane's ambitions, the corruption of politicians, and the general human desire to be loved.  Unfortunately, Welles makes a few missteps in executing these ideas and he tends to concentrate on irrelevancies such as his second wife's attempt at becoming an opera singer.  Perhaps some movie-goers find this suitable, but it is my firm conviction that a film should include scenes which are relevant to the development of the film, and that everything else should be scrapped.  Had Welles concentrated further on his Newspaper organization, and less on his domestic affairs, the plot would seem a lot more coherent.  As a result, it is not clear exactly what Welles is trying to say with this film.  With films like The Godfather, the implications were clear: organized crime is another form of American business.  Taxi Driver implies that loneliness is an ineviatable state of the human race.  This film on the other hand, can't quite make up its mind as to what it wants to get across. <br />   My own feeling is that this film has too many flaws to be really considered on the same level as say \\"The Godfather\\", \\"Seven Samurai\\", or \\"One flew over the cuckoo's nest\\".  The crucial difference being, not only do those films know what they want to say, but the manner in which they say those things is meticulous and free of any redundant words. <br />
0446677450|5.0|Recently in a Toastmaster meeting a speaker told us how we hardly ever challenge what our \\"Mother, Father, Preacher, Teacher\\" (MFPT) taught us. Fact is, times change. We must change with it ... Or, suffer the consequences. <br /> <br />A couple of years ago I received and read a booklet summary of Rich Dad, Poor Dad. To say the least it was a compelling read. In fact, I still display the booklet on my bookshelf for quick inspiration. <br /> <br />Rich Dad, Poor Dad, is a book that teaches six main lessons: <br /> <br />1) The rich don't work for money <br />2) Why teach financial literacy <br />3) Mind your own business <br />4) The history of taxes and the power of corporations <br />5) The rich invent money <br />6) Work to learn - don't work for money <br /> <br />Throughout the lessons, Kiyosaki helps us understand that to achieve financial success we must do something we are never taught in school and that is \\"to think.\\"  <br /> <br />For the budding Entrepreneur, chapters four (Mind your own business) and five (History of taxes and the power of corporations) hold special interest. The first, because \\"there is a big difference between your profession and your business\\" and the second, because taxes are the single largest expense for most of us - at least until we become wise. <br /> <br />Rich Dad, Poor Dad is, at least to me, more than a book about financial literacy, it is about changing your perspective of the world. And that is exactly what this book will help you do. <br /> <br />----------------- <br />Michael Davis - Editor, Byvation

B0008ISM40|5.0|I have read many reviews on here calling this album too similar to the others, and that it should have been the album after The Downward Spiral because it's not close enough to the Fragile. This could not be farther from the truth. With Teeth, in the sound aspect and lyrical aspect, trancends so many fields of music in one album that it is impossible to call it too similar to the other albums. There are tracks that have elements of previous albums in them, but what Nine Inch Nails album did not have tracks that recall tracks from previous albums? And as a whole, With Teeth has a completely different feel to it than Pretty Hate Machine, Broken, The Downward Spiral, and The Fragile. <br /> <br />The themes of With Teeth are strongly tied with Trent Reznor's addiction problems, his coming to grips with the fact he isn't where he thinks he should be, and finally, his facing of himself. These themes work in a concept like The Downward Spiral throughout the album. <br /> <br />I hate reading reviews by those who simply calssify With Teeth as \\"teen angst\\", because it simply isn't. It's a very thoughtfull and meaningful album, for the man who wrote it and for those who listen to it. I love each and every Nine Inch Nails album, and this is no exception. In fact, this is the most interesting of them all. As for fans who were unhappy with the album, I cannot be certain, but I think in time they will learn to like it. It is quite an adjustment from The Fragile to With Teeth. <br /> <br />An incredible album. Mr. Reznor has shown us what real music is once again.

B000929AJQ|4.0|I'm sure you're going to see reviewers lined up saying how bad this album is. Unfortunately, these people haven't given the album the time it needs to truly appreciate this album. First off, this isn't supposed to a Fragile or Downward Spiral. For the first time since 1989, Trent Reznor is writing a song driven album that *GASP* has good songwriting.<br /><br />Trent took everything you know about Nine Inch Nails and left his fans guessing even more this time. This album is unlike any other and is incomparable to previous albums. The best comparison you can make is that this album is Pretty Hate Machine with 13 songs and not about a collective ongoing epic. These songs are the most organic and percussion driven songs that Trent has ever written. Some of that kudos could go to album drummer Dave Grohl, who lets face it, could retire right now with a good name but refuses. From the climatic \\"All the Love in the World\\" to the groove driven title track, Trent knows exactly what he's doing. There are no layers or textures like that of The Fragile or Downward Spiral, but instead is replaced with just creative approaches towards the productions of bass and drums. There are two songs (The Hand That Feeds and Only) that stick out in being \\"radio\\" ready but *GASP* as long as they are good songs I could care less. The last three songs kind of mesh into one long epic that leads to the album's closer \\"Right Where It Belongs\\". This song is so hauntingly beautiful that even Johnny Cash were alive in two years this song would be covered.<br /><br />Words really can't describe how Trent Reznor has lived up to my expectations. Not only did he not continue the long drawn out Fragile sound that would've been old to hear again, but he really took the time to craft out these songs very well. With the re-emergence of New Wave, it's only appropriate that one of the genre's founding fathers has come back to reclaim the throne
0790730960|5.0|This review refers to the Warner Bros. DVD edition of the film. <br /> <br />THE WHO'S WHO: Starring Michael Keaton, Danny DeVito, Michelle Pfeiffer, Christopher Walken, Michael Gough, Pat Hingle, Michael Murphy, Vincent Schiavelli, Andrew Bryniarski, Cristi Conaway, Jan Hooks, Paul Reubens. Based Upon Characters Appearing in Magazines Published By DC Comics Inc. Casting By Marion Dougherty. Special Penguin Makeup and Effects Produced By Stan Winston. Score Composed By Danny Elfman. Co-Executive Produced By Jon Peters. Co-Executive Produced By Peter Guber. Based on Batman Characters Created By Bob Kane. Co-Produced By Denise Di Novi. Co-Produced and Directed By Tim Burton. (PG-13) For Violence, Very Mild Profanity, Very Mild Gore, and Mild Sexual Content; 126m.; 1992. <br /> <br />WHAT'S GOING ON IN HERE?: The best \\"Batman\\" team reunites for a final outing in this blockbuster sequel to the 1989 original. Rising from Gotham City's sewers is the Penguin (Danny DeVito). He hides beneath a facade of humble dignity while plotting to rid Gotham of their first born sons. Falling from the rooftops is the Catwoman (Michelle Pfeiffer). She deals with her abnormal duality by plotting vengeance against the men in her life whom she feels wronged her. Now, Batman (Michael Keaton) must contend with two of the most nefarious supervillians his world has ever known. Director Tim Burton has succeeded in creating a masterpiece which outshines the original movie. This would be a trend carried over by other latter day superhero movies including the \\"X-Men\\", \\"Spider-Man\\" and \\"Blade\\" franchises. The statuesque set pieces are perfect examples of Burton's legendary imagination. Where the original sets for \\"Batman\\" were cold and hard, this Gotham City teems with life and vibrancy. Danny Elfman, as with the original \\"Batman\\" film, reached the pinnacle of his gothic success with his outstanding score. The finale is particularly memorable and showcases what a true talent Elfman really is. Burtonhas also assembled a much better cast for this outrageously entertaining sequel. Keaton returns and continues to infuse his character with the same dry, just-south-of-stuffy performance he brought to the table originally. Michelle Pfeiffer is deliciously slinky in her transformation from painfully shy office secretary Selina Kyle into the aggressive, mysterious Catwoman. She also does a good job portraying the emotional pressures of Catwoman, which leaves her unraveling...literally. Her costume keeps coming apart more and more throughout the picture to physically represent the emotional discrepancies her character is going through. Though, when it's all said and done, Selina Kyle proves that cats really have nine lives. Christopher Walken sinks his teeth into the role of Max Shreck, making the most of an unnecessary character who only serves to fuel the fires of both Catwoman and the Penguin. The true delight, however, is watching Danny DeVito, whose maniacal performance as the Penguin overshadows that of Jack Nicholson (The Joker) from the first film. Overall, this is the best \\"Batman\\" of the bunch. It proves that Warner Bros. should have stuck with the Burton/Keaton formula instead of letting director Joel Schumacher take over the reins for the third movie. One trivia note for astute film buffs, the Penguin's father Tucker Cobblepot is played by Pee-Wee Herman himself, Paul Reubens. <br /> <br />THEY SAY THEY'RE SPECIAL BUT...: When you pop this DVD into your player, it's immediately apparent that the 1.85:1 widescreen transfer is far superior to the one featured on the original 1989 \\"Batman\\" DVD. Colors are crisp and sharp while blacks are even and deep. Every piece of falling confetti and every light on the Christmas trees are easily picked out and clearly defined with very few traces of grain or wear. The 5.1 Dolby surround sound is staggering in its multi-directional capacity and will surprise fans, even the ones like myself who marveled over the surround onthe original motion picture. Particularly captivating are the scenes in which Batman fights the Red Triangle Gang and the explosion Catwoman causes in a Shreck's department store. There's also a French Dolby 2.0 surround sound alongside English, French and Spanish subtitles. Subtitles are clear and easy to read and are framed within the borders of the film itself. The front cover of Warner Bros.' atypical paper case is a recreation of the original 1992 VHS cover, a wonderful arrangement of the three key characters in the film as well as a few scattered penguins across the bottom. The back cover is a refreshing change from the bleak, unimaginative one that adorned the original \\"Batman\\" DVD. The inside of the paper case is actually a bit muddled in its appearance, although it does spotlight the thirty-nine chapter stops for this two hour plus presentation. As with the original \\"Batman\\" DVD, this is a flip disc which features the widescreen version on one side and a scathing, hacked 1.33:1 full screen version on the other side. No notable special features are included on the disc, only the same style of written text found on the first \\"Batman\\" DVD. There's some very brief cast and crew information. There's also some fairly informative production notes which gives back story to \\"Batman\\" creator Bob Kane, the making of the penguin army and some biographical notes for the screenwriters, among other tidbits. Finally, the obligatory \\"Film Flash\\" section is back, which \\"highlights\\" four video covers for other releases Warner Bros. recommends. Once more, the original theatrical trailer is mysteriously absent, which is a shame considering how solid and well-pieced together it was. <br /> <br />THE YOLK'S ON YOU: This is an early release Warner Bros. DVD. You'll probably find the Penguin's underground lair before you find hidden easter eggs on this one. <br /> <br />THE LEWD AND NUDE ALERT: While Michelle Pfeiffer is wonderfully sexy as Catwoman, she's never given the proper progression to express that sexuality on screen. The only sexually charged highlight is seeing her in a form-fitting vinyl catsuit, most notably when she decides to give herself a bath after the Penguin makes her feel dirty. Although, to be fair, the lucky Penguin gets to grope a beautiful fan during his candidacy for mayor. There's very little stimulation in that scene for viewers, only for the Penguin. <br /> <br />THE GORE REPORT: The Penguin bites an unlucky man on his nose and a small stream of blood proceeds to shoot out of the wound. Not bad for a PG-13 rated superhero movie. <br /> <br />SAY AGAIN: \\"What do you want?\\" - Batman (Michael Keaton). \\"Ah, the direct approach. I admire that in a man with a mask.\\" - The Penguin (Danny DeVito). <br /> <br />THE FINAL SAY: Yes, I recommend buying this DVD. I'm not as hesitant about this recommendation as I was on the original \\"Batman\\" DVD. While the special features are lacking, both the video and audio for this sequel are magnificent. Fans of the film will find it a joy to behold. One wishes a commentary track or at least a making of would have graced the extras, but since there are no known plans for a re-release of this DVD, this version will be more than sufficient. <br /> <br />PLAY IT AGAIN, SAM: \\"Face to Face\\" Performed By Siouxsie and the Banshees. Soundtrack Available on Warner Bros. Compact Discs and Cassettes.
B000929AJQ|2.0|The Broken & The Fragile had blown me away. This (with teeth) is nothing short of mediocre. What happened Trent? What were you thinking man? Either you are losing touch with all things musical or you are simply too deafened by your own rants about how bad all the music is out there. You seem to be falling into that very category that you so arduously created in order make people believe that you are the greatest thing in music. It worked for a while, but its clear now that you are NO genius but only play one on TV. Good show man !
0790731002|3.0|This review refers to the Warner Bros. DVD edition of the film. <br /> <br />THE WHO'S WHO: Starring Val Kilmer, Tommy Lee Jones, Jim Carrey, Nicole Kidman, Chris O'Donnell, Michael Gough, Pat Hingle, Drew Barrymore, Debi Mazar, Rene Auberjonois, Joe Grifasi, Jon Favreau, George Wallace, Bob Zmuda, Don \\"The Dragon\\" Wilson, Ed Begley Jr.. Based Upon Characters Appearing in Magazines Published By DC Comics. Special Make-Up Designed and Created By Rick Baker. Score Composed By Elliot Goldenthal. Based on Batman Characters Created By Bob Kane. Co-Produced By Tim Burton. Directed By Joel Schumacher. (PG-13) For Violence and Very Mild Profanity; 121m.; 1995. <br /> <br />WHAT'S GOING ON IN HERE?: The \\"Batman\\" franchise is back, minus the talents of director Tim Burton (who only stayed on as one of the film's producers) and star Michael Keaton (the best Batman to date). In this re-envisioned sequel, Batman goes up against two of his most famous arch-nemeses, Two-Face and the Riddler. The Riddler has designed a new 3-D television box which drains thoughts and memories from the minds of those who use it, transporting that energy into the Riddler's own brain. He's hooked up with Two-Face in order to uncover Batman's secret identity and destroy him once and for all. During one of Two-Face's solo attempts to uncover Batman's identity, he instigates the birth of another new superhero in the form of Robin. So how does this new \\"Batman\\" film stack up against its predecessors? Well, the verdict isn't looking positive by any means. Director Joel Schumacher has fashioned a live action cartoon instead of the brooding, caliginous heroism which graced the first two entries. Score artist Elliot Goldenthal brings an entirely new musical outlook to the franchise which, while not without some merit, makes listeners long for the gothic suspense of Danny Elfman's masterpieces. Val Kilmer gives a stunted performance as the Caped Crusader, appearing more realistic only as his alter ego Bruce Wayne. Where Keaton could pull both halves of the duality off with fine-tuned precision, Kilmer is better suited to bringing Wayne's tortured psyche to the screen rather than competing in the intense action sequences. Tommy Lee Jones looks the most like a comic book portrait during his witless performance. Unlike the Joker and the Penguin from the other movies, Two-Face's make-up seems purposefully arrogant and as far from lifelike as the filmmakers could apparently get. His origin is also carelessly discarded with a mere flashback sequence instead of being fully developed like other supervillains. While Jones does play well enough against the Riddler, he seems overbearing in other areas of the film. Jim Carrey is the beacon of light for the entire movie, acting as if he were born to play the role of the Riddler. His over-the-top performance is almost as memorable as Danny DeVito's interpretation of the Penguin in \\"Batman Returns\\". Carrey makes Edward Nygma's insanity believable and highly enjoyable. Chris O'Donnell is the key player for this film as the origin of Robin figures prominently into the development of the story. Unfortunately, his brash ego can sometimes become irritating and unwelcome to the viewer, a trait that was sadly carried over to \\"Batman and Robin\\" two years later. It's even more shameful since O'Donnell has natural charisma in other films that he wasn't allowed to fully utilize in this one. Ultra brief flashes pop up here and there, but not enough to save his performance. Nicole Kidman is as bright and starry-eyed as she can be in her role, but Dr. Chase Meridian isn't given enough structure to be truly involving as Batman's love interest. Both Michael Gough and Pat Hingle turn in veteran performances, having grown accustomed to their roles over the course of the last two films. Visually, this film begins to fall apart. The Wayne Enterprises and City Hall exteriors are incredible, wondrous pieces of art sandwiched between mediocre, garish neon-oriented sets which are more annoying than awe-inspiring. The Batmobile is a ridiculously fashioned eye sore compared to the original, classic car. An added complication is the fact that the first hour of this film is much slower-paced than the previous two movies. It makes it hard for the viewer to appreciate the characters and the situations the filmmakers have put them in. Overall, this was a nice try that just didn't hit its mark. If Schumacher had tried for a more realistic approach, leaving intact Burton's dark imaginings and lifelike characterizations, this film might have been a success. As it is, it's more of an afterthought to the original two mega-hits. <br /> <br />THEY SAY THEY'RE SPECIAL BUT...: There is a clear 1.85:1 widescreen presentation for this film, though the finale is a bit fuzzy from time to time. Colors are strikingly bold, tending to hurt the viewer's eyes after awhile. Black levels are solid and even but not as noteworthy as they were in \\"Batman Returns\\". Right from the opening moments of this film, the accompanying 5.1 Dolby surround sound makes a noticeable impression. Machine gun blasts leave reverberating traces while explosions are booming, room-shaking events. There's also a French Dolby 2.0 surround sound alongside English, French and Spanish subtitles. As with the previous two films, subtitles are clear and easy to read and are framed within the borders of the film itself. This is another atypical Warner Bros. paper case release, but the cover has a brilliant piece of artwork featuring the five main players from the film. The back is nothing special (but it still beats the original \\"Batman\\" back cover) and the inside highlights the thirty-nine chapter stops for this two hour presentation. As with all entries thus far in the \\"Batman\\" saga, this DVD is a flip disc. The widescreen presentation is on one side while a turgid, cut down 1.33:1 full screen presentation resides on the other. Fans looking for the wealth of background information that should have been made available on this DVD will be sorely let down. All the special features contained on this one are written blurbs such as brief cast and crew notes (which are marginally better than the sections appearing on the \\"Batman\\" and \\"Batman Returns\\" discs) and a production notes section. There's also the inevitable \\"Film Flash\\" which \\"highlights\\" four video covers for other films Warner Bros. recommends. Absent again on a \\"Batman\\" DVD is the original theatrical trailer. While not as intense as the one for \\"Batman Returns\\", the \\"Batman Forever\\" trailer would still have been a welcome addition to the blatantly slim extras on this disc. <br /> <br />THE YOLK'S ON YOU: This is an early Warner Bros. DVD release. You'd be more likely to solve one hundred of the Riddler's best puzzles than you would be to find hidden easter eggs on this one. <br /> <br />THE LEWD AND NUDE ALERT: Nicole Kidman is the main focal point for sexuality in this film. We are treated to seeing the lovely blonde wrapped in a bed sheet when Batman visits her home one night and we also get a very brief upskirt when her character falls out of a glass enclosure. She even tries to seduce Batman on a roof after luring him in with the BatSignal. Her skimpy, lingerie-oriented outfit is nice to look at, but Kidman's been much sexier in other roles (\\"Eyes Wide Shut\\" immediately springs to mind). <br /> <br />THE GORE REPORT: Unlike the previous two films in this franchise, there's not even a trace element of blood to be found. <br /> <br />SAY AGAIN: \\"Riddle me this. Riddle me that. Who's afraid of the big black bat?\\" - The Riddler (Jim Carrey) <br /> <br />THE FINAL SAY: Yes, I recommend buying this DVD. While it's nowhere near as exciting as the last two \\"Batman\\" films, there are still a few enjoyable tidbits to be gleaned from the movie. Any fan of Jim Carrey will find his performance here to be one of his most skillful and humorous. Those who want to give their home theaters a workout will love the 5.1. True \\"Batman\\" enthusiasts can make a passable weekend diversion out of this film. So while it's not a necessary classic for DVD collectors, it's still a reasonably priced, fairly worthy treat if you're looking for a way to kill time. <br /> <br />PLAY IT AGAIN, SAM: \\"Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me, Kill Me\\" Performed By U2. \\"Kiss From a Rose\\" Performed By Seal. \\"Smash it Up\\" Performed By the Offspring. \\"Bad Days\\" Performed By the Flaming Lips. \\"Where Are You Now?\\" Performed By Brandy. Soundtrack Available on Atlantic Compact Discs, Cassettes and Records. Score Available on Atlantic Compact Discs.
B000929AJQ|4.0|I was a NIN freak throughout college (during the NIN heyday of '92-'96), and was underwhelmed by The Fragile, other than several tracks. I kinda wished Reznor would've continued in the vein of Perfect Drug (still my favorite NIN track), but other than Star****ers, The Fragile operated on a totally different key.<br /><br />With Teeth is, well...it's pretty damn poppy. I mean that in a good way, though. I remember when The Fragile came out, a lot of critics opined that it didn't do well commercially and critically because people at that time were more into positive music -- re the late '90s success of Brittney, etc. I wonder if this made Reznor think he needed to do something less angsty?<br /><br />Even though it's coming out 14 years later, With Teeth sounds more like a follow-up to Pretty Hate Machine than any of the preceding NIN albums. Because unlike them, it doesn't operate on one theme, and it isn't a \\"concept album\\" of any sort. It's just a bunch of songs with great production, good beats, good riffs, and insightful lyrics.<br /><br />All the Love in the World:  Starts off like \\"typical\\" NIN, with melodic bass, a brooding atmosphere, and an Autechre-style breakbeat.  Gradually becomes a rocking stomper with piano accompaniment, a mean fuzz bass, a pounding beat, and a sing-along chorus with multiple Reznor vocals that reminds me, well, of like an advertisement or something: \\"I'd like to give the world a Coke,\\" or something...but then again, that might just be me.  Sing-along chorus is \\"Why do you get all the love in the world?\\", and trust me, it WILL get stuck in your head for days after hearing the album.  A great opening track, and unlike any other in the NIN catalog.<br /><br />You Know What You Are:  Reminds me a lot of \\"Burn,\\" from the Natural Born Killers soundtrack.  A computerized drum pattern similar in some ways to \\"March of the Pigs.\\"  Sounds like an old-school NIN rager.  Definite proof that Nine Inch Nails can still pound your head into the ground.  Reznor screams \\"Don't you know what you [expletive] are?\\" in the chorus.<br /><br />The Collector:  Imagine \\"Piggy\\" from The Downward Spiral, only sped up a bit and with more of a dance feel than a jazzy one.  Drums and bass guitar carry the verses, with distorted guitar on bridge and chorus.  I don't think this one would've sounded out of place on The Fragile.  The end descends into an off-kilter, jazzy piano deal that reminds me of David Bowie's \\"Outside\\"- era music.<br /><br />The Hand that Feeds:  It saddens me that so many so-called NIN \\"fans\\" deride this track as a \\"sell-out,\\" \\"too poppy,\\" etc.  It's as if these freaks have never heard Pretty Hate Machine.  In all honesty, this could stand as one of my favorite NIN tracks ever.  It's got Pretty Hate Machine-era rhythm, Broken-era guitars, and great lyrics.  It's the perfect symbiosis of NIN's early dance roots and later industrial-metal rage.<br /><br />Love is Not Enough:  Starts off slow and foreboding.  Has that Pretty Hate Machine sound, only more modern, with more \\"live\\" instrumentation, except for the drums, which are a sampled beat.  Wicked guitars on the chorus, totally distorted.  Reznor does that \\"speaking/singing\\" thing during the verses.  Toward the end, some very cool harmonics guitars pop up against the main riff.<br /><br />Every Day is Exactly the Same:  If there was ever an album titled \\"Pretty Hate Machine II,\\" this track would be on it.  It's got the keyboard rhythm foundation, the hummable melody, the sing-along chorus.  Hearing this, it's hard to imagine this is the same guy who gave us \\"March of the Pigs.\\"  Middle section features Reznor speaking/singing about leaving a letter for a lover.<br /><br />With Teeth:  Starts off like \\"Piggy,\\" again: heavy, jazzy drums from a real-life drummer, with fuzz bass and distorted guitar accompaniment.  I like this track a lot, it's another example of how Reznor can take something so foreboding and craft it into a melody that sticks in your brain.Unfortunately, the track drops off three minutes in for a long spell of piano ambience, which some may find \\"arty,\\" but I just find annoying.  Goes on for a little over a minute before the song itself comes back with force, this time with distorted guitars blaring throughout.  ROCK!<br /><br />Only:  After hearing the first few beats, you half-expect Gwen Stefani or Pink to start singing.  Seriously, it's THAT poppy.  You could probably argue that this track sounds more like something off Pretty Hate Machine than any other on With Teeth, like a cross between \\"Down In It\\" and \\"Sin.\\"  Reznor speaks the lyrics throughout the verse: \\"Sometimes I can see right through myself.\\"  Those who are quick to scream \\"sell-out\\" will hate this track more than any other, but I like it a lot.  Word of caution: the bass riff will get stuck in your head, guaranteed.<br /><br />Getting Smaller:  This track rocks, plain and simple.  But it doesn't rock like an older NIN track, like \\"Wish\\" or \\"Burn;\\" it rocks more like something by the Foo Fighters or recent Primal Scream.  Ever wondered what NIN would sound like if they were a \\"traditional\\" hard rock group, without industrial instrumentation like keyboards, samples, and loops?  Well, wonder no more.  Raging guitars, pounding drums, screamed vocals, this is a definite standout.  \\"My world is getting smaller everyday, and that's okay.\\"<br /><br />Sunspots:  Another slow and mellow track with heavy drums and a thick bass.  The chorus features the most melodic use of white noise I've ever heard.  The guitars crop up eventually, and the rhythm speeds up a little, but this one's a slow burner all the way.<br /><br />The Line Begins to Blur:  Sounds a lot like something from The Fragile.  Distorted rhythm section, repetitive beat.  Reznor screams the lyrics, sounding like he's down a well.  The chorus seems to be from a different song altogether, very melodic and mellow.<br /><br />Beside You in Time:  Another track with that Fragile-era sound.  Reznor provides mellow vocals over a pulsing synth riff, with a drum loop quietly pounding beneath.  This goes on without much variation until everything drops out except for the synths, which throb louder and louder until they explode into a welter of distorted guitars, which chug along on the same riff.  A GREAT moment.  Sounds truly evil.  As if to contradict this malevolent vibe, Reznor provides airy, dreamy vocals, which seem to float unscathed above the din.<br /><br />Right Where It Belongs:  Similar in many ways to \\"Hurt,\\" off Downward Spiral, especially the live version which can be found on Further Down the Spiral.  Mellow and depressed, a piano provides the melody, with sinister feedback zapping alongside it.  No drums.  Reznor sounds a bit like he's on a short-wave radio.  Eventually a sampled live audience appears, further giving it that \\"Hurt\\" sound.  Doesn't build up to a crescendo; instead, it ends with the piano playing solo.  A saddened ending to an otherwise upbeat album.<br /><br />Here's something funny: while writing this review, and mentally comparing the tracks with those on previous NIN albums, I've realized this is my favorite Nine Inch Nails album.  It's not as sterile as The Fragile, it's more song-oriented than The Downward Spiral, it's longer than Broken, and it's more edgy than Pretty Hate Machine.  Every track has something great, and overall it's one hell of an enjoyable listen.  Besides, who needs \\"all angst, all the time?\\"  It's a new millennium, let's try to make it a more positive one.hat sticks in your brain.  Unfortunately, the track drops off three minutes in for a long spell of piano ambience, which some may find \\"arty,\\" but I just find annoying.  Goes on for a little over a minute before the song itself comes back with force, this time with distorted guitars blaring throughout.  ROCK! <br /> <br />Only:  After hearing the first few beats, you half-expect Gwen Stefani or Pink to start singing.  Seriously, it's THAT poppy.  You could probably argue that this track sounds more like something off Pretty Hate Machine than any other on With Teeth, like a cross between \\"Down In It\\" and \\"Sin.\\"  Reznor speaks the lyrics throughout the verse: \\"Sometimes I can see right through myself.\\"  Those who are quick to scream \\"sell-out\\" will hate this track more than any other, but I like it a lot.  Word of caution: the bass riff will get stuck in your head, guaranteed. <br /> <br />Getting Smaller:  This track rocks, plain and simple.  But it doesn't rock like an older NIN track, like \\"Wish\\" or \\"Burn;\\" it rocks more like something by the Foo Fighters or recent Primal Scream.  Ever wondered what NIN would sound like if they were a \\"traditional\\" hard rock group, without industrial instrumentation like keyboards, samples, and loops?  Well, wonder no more.  Raging guitars, pounding drums, screamed vocals, this is a definite standout.  \\"My world is getting smaller everyday, and that's okay.\\" <br /> <br />Sunspots:  Another slow and mellow track with heavy drums and a thick bass.  The chorus features the most melodic use of white noise I've ever heard.  The guitars crop up eventually, and the rhythm speeds up a little, but this one's a slow burner all the way. <br /> <br />The Line Begins to Blur:  Sounds a lot like something from The Fragile.  Distorted rhythm section, repetitive beat.  Reznor screams the lyrics, sounding like he's down a well.  The chorus seems to be from a different song altogether, very melodic and mellow.  <br /> <br />Beside You in Time:  Another track with that Fragile-era sound.  Reznor provides mellow vocals over a pulsing synth riff, with a drum loop quietly pounding beneath.  This goes on without much variation until everything drops out except for the synths, which throb louder and louder until they explode into a welter of distorted guitars, which chug along on the same riff.  A GREAT moment.  Sounds truly evil.  As if to contradict this malevolent vibe, Reznor provides airy, dreamy vocals, which seem to float unscathed above the din. <br /> <br />Right Where It Belongs:  Similar in many ways to \\"Hurt,\\" off Downward Spiral, especially the live version which can be found on Further Down the Spiral.  Mellow and depressed, a piano provides the melody, with sinister feedback zapping alongside it.  No drums.  Reznor sounds a bit like he's on a short-wave radio.  Eventually a sampled live audience appears, further giving it that \\"Hurt\\" sound.  Doesn't build up to a crescendo; instead, it ends with the piano playing solo.  A saddened ending to an otherwise upbeat album.             <br />   <br />Here's something funny: while writing this review, and mentally comparing the tracks with those on previous NIN albums, I've realized this is my favorite Nine Inch Nails album.  It's not as sterile as The Fragile, it's more song-oriented than The Downward Spiral, it's longer than Broken, and it's more edgy than Pretty Hate Machine.  Every track has something great, and overall it's one hell of an enjoyable listen.  Besides, who needs \\"all angst, all the time?\\"  It's a new millennium, let's try to make it a more positive one.
B000929AJQ|5.0|I've never written a review for ANYTHING before until now, after 3 cd run-throughs.  Wow.  Trent has always been ahead of his time.  Please ignore the reviews that say this album is awful or even average.  Whether your somewhat of a NIN fan, or a matured music listener (Appreciate music and genres as artforms), it takes a couple listens to first get a feel for it initially.  From there comes replay value.  NIN is one of the few bands that successfully incorperates long-term replay value into their work.  For example, I only initially liked maybe 5-7 songs off of \\"The Fragile\\".  The others seemed, I don't know, I just didn't have the feel.  5 years after that I gave it a listen and suddenly found myself loving everysong........ <br /> <br />Onto With_Teeth.... <br />I've never really referred to music as being \\"beautiful\\" until this album.  Even the harder, upbeat songs have well thoughtout melodies that just flow.  Also, i've never felt like I got my \\"moneys-worth\\" as much as with this.  It's a very complex album due to the fact that Trent is a genius and NIN molds and evolves throughout every song and album, albums being more noticible. <br /> <br />Some reviews have listed \\"stand out\\" tracks.  Being a true NIN fan I must say that no single track stands out, but every track on the album absolutly blew me away.  I was hoping to hear tracks with the same vibe as \\"March of the pigs\\" and \\"Mr. Self destruct\\", but I know realize I'm happier that \\"repeat\\" sounds are not what NIN is about.  Those older tracks are in my NIN library of HALOS and can be enjoyed anytime.  \\"With Teeth\\" adds to the library a completely new sounding set of tracks, all unique and well though out.  Can't wait to see them on tour.... <br /> <br />With NIN albums individual song reviews are hard as any NIN fan would know.... <br /> <br />So if you purchase this album,(HIGHLY RECOMMENDED - see first line of this review) you can expect: <br /> <br />-Well established percussion and beats that are unique and changing throughout the entire album. <br />-Lyrics that mostly ponder the thoughts about life (Why are we here?) <br />-Emotions are not forced upon you in this album, but drawn out of you depending on your mood.  This strongly adds to replay value as you discover new things each listen. <br />-****Important****  This is the thing that draws the line between people loving or hating this album.  The random, industrual-like sounds have been suppressed with this album...it seems now that they are more organized into the main rythem..(I haven't had chance to try 5.1 format) <br /> <br />Hope this gives you and idea of how the album is, and whether your a true NIN fan or not. <br />  <br /> <br />

6304806434|2.0|Don't misunderstand me, in LIKE high energy action movies that don't make a lot of sense if you insist on taking them apart. Unfortunately this one stumbles right out of the gate. The whole premise of the movie depends on the audience believing in Mr. Cage's predicament, and I can't. <br /> <br />Supposedly, he has been in prison for years because he, a decorated combat vet, was assaulted by a gang of toughs outside a bar where he had gone to pick up his wife and take her home, and he killed one of them. I don't buy it; not for a minute. Let's say, for the sake of argument, that the creep he killed was the local sheriff's son, and that the local political machine is strong enough to get a conviction. I still have to believe that sometime in the first year the Governor of the state is going to call his good buddy, the Sheriff, and say \\"Merle, I know  you loved that no good son of yours, but there's an election coming up. If I don't pardon this guy he's going to be the campaign issue that sinks me. I'm writing a pardon.\\" <br /> <br />That, or he wins on first appeal. The idea that a combat vet is going to rot in prison for years for defending himself from assault is absurd. It undermines the entire film. It is too much to ask the audience to buy. <br /> <br />Otherwise the movie is no sillier than most of its type. There are some genuinely fine moments, and it is full of great energy. It's too bad the film makers threw away any chance of maintaining my minimal standards of belief for such films in the first minutes.

If you enjoy this album and are looking for some similar great roots albums then I recommend the following: <br />1) Appalachian Stomp: Bluegrass Classics  <br />2) Ain't No Grave: A Tribute To Traditional And Public Domain Songs <br />3) March 16-20 by Uncle Tupelo <br />4) Beautiful Dreamer: The Songs Of Stephen Foster <br />5) Every Sound Below by Tim Eriksen <br />
B0000399WI|5.0|This film sticks in my mind as one of the best movies I've seen for several reasons, but primarily because of the outstanding character and plot development.  Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, is a quiet man who was unjustly convicted of murder and sent to Shawshank State Prison. While there he meets Red, played by Morgan Freeman, who is a lifer and also the go-to guy if anybody needs anything from the outside world. All the inmates respect Red, including Andy, who feels completely out of place in the prison world. He knows that this is not the place for him, and it is his determined hope to eventually get out that causes him to persevere. He, too, eventually gains the respect of the other inmates, although he never fully connects with them. For him, prison is just a temporary station in life and he refuses to attach himself to any part of it. <br /> <br />As the film progresses the audience is captivated by the developing relationship between Red and Andy. We watch them grow together and we can see the impact that they have on each other; we also watch expectantly as we view the impact that both characters have on the prison itself. The development of the characters draws us in-we feel personally connected to them and as twists in the story take place we are anxious to see what happens to each of these characters. <br /> <br />As the story draws the audience in, we wonder just what will happen next. We see mini-plots emerge, including the story of one elderly prisoner who is released back into a world he hardly knows. Because the world has changed so drastically since he was first incarcerated and because he misses his friends so deeply, he takes his own life. His freedom just wasn't worth the loneliness he felt. Watching this, we wonder what will happen to Red and Andy if they are ever released. Will they feel the same way or will they be able to move on with their life? The overall dynamics of the storyline are so engaging that at the end of the film it is difficult to find closure. We are left wondering what is going to happen next. We want to keep following the characters and their story. <br /> <br />This film is engaging, cleverly worked together, and wonderfully developed. Superb acting and an engrossing storyline are finely knit together to produce this masterpiece. <br />
0679731377|5.0|I rarely enjoy fiction very much. For instance, last year I read \\"Life of Pi,\\" which for some reason everyone seems to rave about, and I thought it was just ok. I thought \\"The Alchemist\\"  was terrible, but many intelligent people endorse it. Now I'm reading \\"Lonesome Dove\\" and finding it slow going. But I'm not totally biased against the genre; I read Kafka's \\"The Metamorphosis\\" recently, and loved it. I can't get enough of Tolstoy, Dostoyevsky or Orwell. But they're all dead, aren't they? So there's some background on my tastes, and an explanation for why, despite a strong recommendation from an intelligent friend of good taste, I didn't expect to like this book very much.<br /><br />Sure enough, I thought the first chapter was moderately entertaining, but predictable. That changed as the book went on: Barnes is a very nice writer; the first chapter was probably the most difficult to write. Immediately the book gets more interesting. From the beginning of the second or third chapter, you realize that Barnes is playing with you. The simplicity is deceiving and you have the opportunity to think hard if you want to. The better chapters are sometimes even subtly shocking, yet they remain light and playful. On the other hand, the last chapter is very simple but I will probably never forget it. I may even try to write my own version of it.<br /><br />The book is quite challenging, full of philosophy written into flesh. Barnes manages to tread a fine line between being sufficiently post-modern to please the chattering literature types, and being traditional enough to please more critical folks like me. I was pleased.<br /><br />I don't want to give away anything, other reviewers will certainly do that if you are interested. But I will confidently recommend this book to anyone who enjoys reading an intelligent story. Interestingly, as with \\"Life of Pi,\\" not too far below the surface, this is a book about religion. But whereas \\"Life of Pi\\" is advertised as a book that will make you believe in God, I would advertise this as a book that will make you an atheist. Of course that's all just wind, but this is a very satisfying and clever book.<br /><br />I want to especially recommend it to folks who, like me, sometimes find themselves defending the theory of evolution to its fundamentalist critics. It's very entertaining from this point of view.I would advertise this as a book that will make you an atheist. Of course that's all just wind, but this is a very satisfying and clever book.     I want to especially recommend it to folks who, like me, sometimes find themselves defending the theory of evolution to its fundamentalist critics. It's very entertaining from this point of view.
